turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, let's talk about liberty, because let's talk about what the Fourteenth Amendment talks about.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Alright, the Fourteenth Amendment talks about certain areas in which the State may not interfere arbitrarily, and one of --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Life, liberty or property.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: That's right, and we --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And we've eliminated two of them, and we're left with liberty.
Now, what liberty of the child is being taken away?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: We are talking about the liberty of the child in the foster-family relationship.
One of the zones of privacy that the Fourteenth Amendment has been held to protect --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It doesnâ€™t talk about -- let's try to answer my question first, and then you can explain all you want.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: It is the childâ€™s interest in the family relationship, Your Honor.
That's a liberty interest.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Has that ever been identified as a liberty before in any other case anywhere?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: The family relationship has repeatedly been identified as a liberty interest.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The childâ€™s liberty, or has it been the parents', the natural parents'?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: There has never been a conflict between parent and child before; but in Stanley v. Illinois, the Court spoke about the family relationship, both from the standpoint of the father and from the standpoint of the child.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, as Armstrong v. Manzo, too; but that involved a parent's interest, the natural parentâ€™s interest.
This is a foster childâ€™s liberty interest, and I'm interested in how you would describe that.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Well, there has not been a case in which this has specifically been held.
There is no question about that, and I am not suggesting that, but the child has a liberty interest in the relationship, which this Court has repeatedly found to be a protected relationship.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, where has this Court ever identified any such liberty?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: This Court has identified the liberty interest in family relationships from the standpoint, as you say, of the natural family.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The natural parents, yes.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: The natural parents, that's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's in Stanley v. Illinois, Armstrong v. Manzo and, I 'm sure, other cases.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: That's right.
I find it hard to believe that the Court would limit that only to the natural parent and not have the right flow two ways.
Children have been held to have liberty interests in other situations.
That is --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Certainly, if they're put in jail, they have an interest in not being put in jail and if they're a child, they could have all kinds of liberty interests.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: They also have an interest in not being arbitrarily suspended from school, both based on their property interest and their liberty interest and in addition to that, Your Honor, I would like to point out that the Fifth Circuit just a month ago in a decision yet unreported found a liberty interest both from simply the foster parent and the foster child in an analogous situation, citing this case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: As my brother Stevens suggested in a question a few moments ago, if the foster child does have this liberty interest which is constitutionally protected by the procedural due process accorded by the Fourteenth Amendment.
Why isnâ€™t that interest protected if the foster parents don't want him in the home?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Well, I think that as a reasonable matter --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, it is still the same liberty interest if it is the childâ€™s interest, isnâ€™t it?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, and --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why on earth did the District Court say that no hearing is required if the foster parents don't want him in the home?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, this Court could, of course, modify the decision in that respect.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, why do you think it did?
Why do you think the District Court did if the liberty interest was the kind of interest you're describing?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: The District Court did it after submission of affidavits by the City Defendants, in which they made a policy argument that there was no need to have a hearing and it would be counterproductive to have a hearing in a situation in which foster parents were requesting the removal and that, in fact, it might be destructive to a child to require the child to stay there during the hearing process when the foster family had affirmatively asked that the child to leave.
That was the basis for the District Court exempting that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, then the liberty interest, I guess our description ought to be narrowed somewhat.
It's an interest in remaining in a willing foster parentâ€™s home.
Is that it?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: That is right, Your Honor, in which there is a relationship that could be protected there.
I'd like to also address myself to another question that you raised earlier, and that is whether or not the state court review process is in effect when a child is being removed from a foster home.
It is not.
The state court review process is a review of status which takes place periodically.

Ms. Smith had had a review of foster-care status with regard to these children only two weeks before the children were to be removed from her home, and the record shows that the agencies do not require the court to order that the children be removed before the children actually are removed.

The Foster-Care Review status is a hearing in which the child is determined to remain in public care, in foster care generally, and in which the agency is free then to move the child anyplace, as they were preparing to do in Ms. Smithâ€™s case so that there are not other available ways in which the liberty interest could be protected.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what do you think is defective about the present procedures of ten days' notice and then a sit-down conference?
Isnâ€™t there an opportunity for a sit-down, at least a conversation with the agency?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Yes, there is.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And can the foster parents bring any information they have there?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: They can bring information; but they don't know the reason that the child is going to be removed, so they are somewhat handicapped.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Are they ever told?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: They may or they may not be, and it may or may not be the reason for which the child is going to be removed; the record is very clear on this.
They don't know the reason for the child being moved in many cases.
If the reason for the child being removed is based on a report in the record, they do not have access for that.
They have a person who is conducting the conference who has already presented them.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, do you agree that under State law that when a parent voluntarily turns over his child to the State to place in a foster home?
Do you agree that the understanding is or the State law is that the parent has the right to have the child back upon request?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: The State law says that, that's right; but there are certain exceptions.
I think that the situations vary enormously.
The Gandy childrenâ€™s mother voluntarily placed these children with the State.
We are talking about situations in which at least a year has passed; often, much more time has passed.
I don't believe that the State law says that the natural parents have an absolute right; in fact, State law has changed since this decision and has been modified somewhat.
So now a hearing that might be directed by this Court could look into a few other things, depending on the length of time the child had been out.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: By the way, what standard do you think the agency in New York applies now when after a year there's a removal from a foster home proposed and they give the foster parent notice?
What standard do you think the agency is applying in deciding to remove the child to return it to the parent?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: I think the standard varies.
I think that the standard that would be articulated --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what's applied, do you find it in the statute or in the regulation?
Where do you find it?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: If the statute says that, 383(2) says that an agency may remove a child from a foster home at the agencyâ€™s discretion.
That's the standard in the statute.
Agencies generally operate under the rubric that they are acting in the best interests of the child, but the agency decision-making process --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, as far as the standard is concerned, that is all right with you, I take it?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: That certainly is, but it is obviously a sufficiently vague and subjective standard at which a lot of subjective information is relevant so that --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, it may be; but you would not suggest that the standard be changed.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: No.
No, Your Honor, all we are suggesting is that there has to be some sort of an adequate procedure to determine whether the standard has been correctly applied.

I do not think that anyone at this point will assert that the standard was correctly applied with regard to the removal of Eric and Danielle Gandy from Ms. Smithâ€™s home, and in fact the agency itself changed workers and reversed itself.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is the agency decision in New York subject to any kind of judicial review?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: No, the agency decision is subject to the conference that the District Court declared unconstitutional, and then the child may be removed.
After the child is removed, there is a full administrative fair hearing provided by Section 400 of the Social Services Law.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And then that is subject to judicial review.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: And then that is subject to judicial review, perhaps many, many months and years down the road after the child has been subjected to an incorrect decision.

After Eric and Danielle, for example, could have been out of Ms. Smithâ€™s home for a year-and-a-half by the time this case could have gotten into State Court to review whether or not Ms. Smith indeed had arthritis that made her incapable of caring for the children.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you think the District Court would require that the full trial-type hearing prior to removal be subject to judicial review?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Well, I do not think that they required a full trial-type hearing; but I think it was their intention, I think the opinion specifically says, that they contemplate this to be the final administrative decision.
So that judicial review could be obtained immediately, and if any stay was going to be granted that of course would be up to the court; it hardly would be automatic.

But I think that they were trying to make this decision-making process as speedy as possible rather than allowing the present procedure, which contemplates a conference first, the removal and then full-scale review after the harm has already been done, so that in a sense the harm is really irrevocable, because the child has already been subjected to a removal, which may have not been necessary and which constitutional standards we believe could require and make much more adequate in terms of making a decision for these children.
We are talking about children who are being separated from what may be the only home they know.
We're talking --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Ms. Lowry, could I just put this other side of the problem to you for a moment?
Supposing the agency adopted a rule that in a single foster-parent situation -- Ms. Smith was a 53-year-old widow.
A single parent over 52 or 53 years old suffering from a severe illness of some kind such as arthritis should not in the normal case retain custody of the child such as this.
Would such a rule be arbitrary?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: I think it would not be subject to Federal Court jurisdiction.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, if that were adopted as agency policy and you impose the hearing, who shall decide whether or not the policy should apply in a he given case?
It is going to be an employee of the agency, isnâ€™t it?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: No, the person who would decide whether the decision was arbitrary would be a public official.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Now, who is this independent decision-maker?
That's the question I was getting at.
What does the Constitution require with respect to the identity of the person who shall decide whether or not to apply the policy?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: I think that the only thing that the Constitution requires here is that the decision-maker not be previously involved in the decision.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But where does the Constitution require that?
Why isnâ€™t it perhaps wiser to have a person who has some background with the family and the child and all the rest making the decision?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Well, I think -- first of all, there is nothing to require that this decision-maker not be someone with some background in Social Services.
But because --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, but with knowledge of the facts of this particular case.
Why does that disqualify a person otherwise independent, having no financial interest, no interest other than the wellbeing of the child?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Because the people who then appear before the decision-maker who want to present the information to the decision-maker are burdened by the fact that the decision-maker has knowledge of a great deal of information that the other people may not know of and may not have an opportunity to refute.

If the Social Servicesâ€™ official has been involved in the decision, as the record shows many of them were, then they may have access to a great deal of information that, in fact, is not accurate; and when the family and the childâ€™s representative or the child comes in to explain why the decision is incorrect, then the people who come in to explain that will not know about what information the decision-maker has in his or her head, and they can't refute it.
That is why it is important the decision-maker make a decision based on information that's presented then that each side can have an opportunity to refute.
This doesn't require lawyers.
It can be as informal as people sitting down and talking.

But the decision cannot be made fairly unless all parties know what the other side has to say and have an opportunity to say, "This fact is wrong, but this fact is right" or "The fact is half-right and half-wrong".

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Ms. Lowry, I am still in trouble.
Is this person a person outside of the agency?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: The person is an employee of the Social Service district, and if the child is in care with the Social Service district --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I mean, I'm talking about the one you want.
Will you settle for that?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.
I think we are talking about the same kind of decision-maker as in Goldberg.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The only one you want is somebody that didnâ€™t handle this particular case.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: We want someone who was not involved in this particular case who will make a decision based on the information presented to them at the time everybody has an opportunity to hear the information.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, is the man and woman at the conference such a person?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: At the conference itself.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: At the conference, no.
The person at the conference, the record shows, usually was involved in the decision-making at the initial stages.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But you would settle if it was another equivalent person -- for example, somebody had another authorized case, but didn't have this one.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: That is right, but we would --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You'd be satisfied.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Yes, but we would say that it cannot be someone from the private agency; it has to be a public official, as the conference now requires.
These are private agencies that are publicly funded and are delegated with the responsibility of taking care of these children.
It is a public function, and we would say that an in-agency conference would not be adequate; but a Social Service agency conference just as was contemplated in Goldberg v. Kelly would be adequate.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you don't want to overhaul the whole Social Services.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: No, Your Honor, not at all.
We are asking only for the same kind of decision-maker as is presently provided in the revised City procedure.
We are not asking for a different kind of decision-maker.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, all these arguments go to what kind of piece of legislation the State of New York ought to have dealing with this sensitive subject.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I believe not.

The District Court said that the exact details of the procedure should be worked out by New York; but the question of whether or not there should be a procedure and whether or not it should satisfy minimal due process with the right of everyone to be heard I believe is a Federal issue and is a constitutional issue.

And I believe that these children have been condemned to suffer grievous loss, they do have a constitutionality protected interest in the relationship, in this family relationship, which may be their only family relationship and their only hope for permanence.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what I can't understand is that they are going to --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Who are you representing, the interests of the children or the foster parents?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: I am here representing the interests of the foster family.
As you know, Your Honor, I represent the foster parents.
They have an interest in the foster-family relationship.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, you were just speaking about the childrenâ€™s rights.
I thought your friend was representing their interests and the State's.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Well, it is our position that we represent the foster childrenâ€™s rights as articulated by the District Court.

Ms. Buttenwieser, as you know, has not requested such relief; the foster parents have requested such relief, and we believe we have standing to raise the childrenâ€™s interests with regard to this right.
Mr. Justice Rehnquist, I'm sorry, I did not hear your question.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You had a problem common on many counsel, being peppered by more than one member of the Court at a time.
What is the issue that this hearing is supposed to resolve?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Alright, with regard to the most common situation, 80% of the situations in which the child is being removed from the foster home and to be transferred someplace else.
The hearing is to decide whether the transfer is in the childâ€™s best interests.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And is the reason that that is because New York says that is what the issue is?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: New York says that children can be removed at the agencyâ€™s discretion.
I believe that New York also takes as a matter of legislative policy the decisions made with regard to children should be made in their best interests.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But now, is this question to be answered at the hearing one that has its direct source in New York law, or is it superimposed as part of the constitutional guarantee by the District Court?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: No, the District Court did not --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Which?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: I'm sorry.
The District Court did not deal with standards at all.
The District Court was very explicit, the questions to be answered at the hearing about what' in the best interests of the children are a matter solely of State policy.
There is not Federal policy that is imposed by the District Court decision.

The District Court says that the hearing is only to adequately effectuate State policy and that it is constitutionally required, but to effectuate State policy and not to impose any kinds of Federal policy.

The question to be answered when the child is going to be returned to a natural parent is the question that is detailed by State law, it is a-State law standard that has to be applied then, and it is a different standard than when the child is going to go to another foster family; but it is determined by State law.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And each of these standards is now applied by various New York public agencies, but just not in the same manner as the District Court thinks they ought to be applied.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: They are not applied in a constitutionally adequate manner, and the decision is not reviewed in any kind of a constitutionally required manner until after the child is out of the home.
It is reviewed after the child is out of the home.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Ms. Lowry, could I ask another question?
The foster parents' status as having authority to receive foster children is something that's renewed periodically, is it?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Yes, it is.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does the child have any right to protest the withdrawal of a license of a foster home?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: The child does not under New York law, but that would be -- that would likely --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: This could happen, could it not, for example, if they might adopt a rule that no one over 50 years of age with arthritis can be a foster parent?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: The State could do that, that's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And without any notice or a hearing to a child who might be affected by such a decision.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Well, I think that if a child were in a foster home and there was such a relationship, then the fact that the license was going to be withdrawn would be an issue at the hearing; and I believe under the District Court decision that would require a hearing, and I believe even under the existing procedures.
There is presently a procedure where that foster parent could challenge the determination of withdrawal of the license; but that would be again after the child is removed.
Section 400, I believe, contemplates that; but that again is after the harm has been done, the unnecessary harm.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But the logic of the District Courtâ€™s opinion would seem to require that the child whose liberty was going to be deprived by the laws of license by the foster family would be the party interested in such a hearing.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Constitutionally.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Yes and --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And he or she would have a right to procedural due process accorded by the Fourteenth Amendment before New York could cancel a license of a foster parent...

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Yes, and I believe --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: His or her foster parent.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: That's right.

I believe that's a situation covered by the District Courtâ€™s order, because in that case the reason for the removal would be the cancellation of the license, and then there would be a hearing at which it could be determined whether it was in the best interests of the child then to be removed from that foster home.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Ms. Lowry, suppose the District Court in another case says that before the child surrendered by its own parents can be accepted by the State, there must be a hearing.
Would you complain about that?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Not at all, Your Honor.
In fact --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You would want that.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: We would want that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I mean, in other words, you're saying that nothing can be done concerning the child without a hearing.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: No, we're not saying nothing can be done without a --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, can the foster parent paddle the child without a hearing?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: Yes, as long as it's not excessive.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That doesn't have anything to do with liberty at all, does it?

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I don't think it does; I think that that becomes a State-law issue whether --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: (Inaudible) I didn't hear it.

turn.speaker: marcia_robinson_lowry
turn.label: Ms. Marcia Robinson Lowry
turn.text: No, Your Honor, I think that the only time a hearing is required is when there is going to be a substantial deprivation to the children, and we think that children should not come into foster care unnecessarily.
We think that the best thing for a child is to stay with the natural family under most circumstances; we have no quarrel with that.

All we're saying is that after time has passed and after a child has been in the relationship for a year or more, the child then has an interest in the relationship and has an interest in not being subjected to arbitrary deprivation of that relationship.
We're not talking at all about substantive standards when we're talking about the natural family.
Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Ms. Marcus?

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: Your Honor, let me just point to the record to correct a few errors that were made in appellees' argument.

So far as the statistics are concerned, Page 90(a) of the Appendix contains a projection based on '75 and early '76 figures, which state that as to New York City there would 4,200 removals or changes of status.
Half of those would be children discharged from foster care so that we've got half being transferred within, half being discharged out.
Now, in figures by the Childrenâ€™s Child Welfare Information Service, which is a computerized service that keeps records on this for the agencies and for the City.

1975 figures were attached to interveners' reply brief, and that showed that of the discharges -- and now, we are talking about half of transfers, half are within the system, half out -- of the half that goes out.
In the year 1975 of the group of children in foster care for more than a year, 48.1% returned to the natural parents.
So those are the statistical facts as shown by the record.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what about appellees' argument that there is no liberty interest or that if there is one all the process that is due is being afforded?

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: Both, Your Honor, there can't be a liberty interest, because if there were one it would collide head-on with the one already declared by this Court to the natural family, first for the reason that I stated before, that the standard has got to change.
If we're going to have --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does this case only involve cases where the natural parent wants the children back?

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: No, but the point is that once you declare a liberty interest in the foster-care relationship, it is going to change the...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what if a natural parent isn't involved and it's just the State has decided to change the custody?

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: The State cannot guarantee a liberty interest in a relationship out of which one party can walk at any time.
The natural parents --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, would you say anybody could complain at all if New York decided, well, we've been giving too much due process here.

We are going to discontinue foster care at the discretion of the agencies without any hearing, without any notice, without any sit-down discussion, without any trial-type hearing at all, and not subject to any judicial review whatsoever.
We're just going to transfer the children.

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: Well, that would abrogate 392, of course.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I just said let's assume New York decides to do it.

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: That decides to abrogate existing statutes.
I think New York is not under any constitutional obligation to provide any foster-care services.
This is --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that isn't what I asked you.

They are providing it, and they are going to make, say, 2,000 transfers a year in New York City from one foster family to another and without any hearing, without any notice, without explaining anything at all and without any judicial review.
Now, you would say they could do that, because there is no liberty interest whatsoever.

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: Yes, I would say that although as a matter of policy, obviously that would be undesirable and would not be done under New York law.
You cannot have a liberty interest in a relationship in which one party has no obligation whatever to remain with it.
Imagine what would happen if a natural parent or an adoptive parent decided to walk out of a relationship.
They would be jailed, and they would be publicly stigmatized.
There is a great difference between an adoptive and natural parent and the foster parent here, there is no obligation.
Ms. Goldberg was obligated only so long as she took the Stateâ€™s money.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Would you think that State could without any notice whatsoever and without any hearing terminate the parentsâ€™ rights once --

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: The natural parentsâ€™ rights?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is because why?

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: Because this Court has declared that there is a constitutional right for a natural family to be together, and under this Court's decision it would not --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you think the child's --

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: The decisions would not be possible to abrogate the rights of a natural family.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you think the child himself would have an interest in that interest?
Do you think the child would have standing?

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: Well, as a member of the natural family, he would partake of that interest; but that does not occur here.
And I might add as to the second part of your question --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So you agree that the child certainly has a liberty interest in remaining with his natural family.

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: Yes, this Court has so declared and we are under this Courtâ€™s mandate.
Now insofar as --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But not with respect to remaining with any foster family.

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: Foster family because of the complete difference in that kind of relationship.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Suppose the parents are dead, and the State has custody of the child.

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: The State always has custody in the case where the child is in foster care, and then of course the foster parents by statute have a mandatory statutory preference to become the adoptive parents in that situation

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, does anyone have standing -- would anybody have any kind of standing whatsoever or any interest that you would recognize to question the State's decision in terminating a particular foster parent?

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: Well, I want to correct also a misconception about 392, which came up in appelleesâ€™ argument, 392 of the Social Services Law.
The foster parent can ask the court to maintain that child in his home.
It does operate as a possible pre-removal judicial hearing, and there are a number of cases cited in our brief where that was done.
It does not have to wait until years and years later.
This is a pre-removal judicial hearing which is available.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And in what court?

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: And that is in the Family Court of the State of New York.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's not the United States District Court.

turn.speaker: maria_l_marcus
turn.label: Ms. Maria L. Marcus
turn.text: No, this is in the Family Court of the State of New York, and of course with usual appeals and eventually to this Court if there's something amiss.
Now, Justice Stevens brought up the question of whether the decision below contemplated the child having some role, the decision below didn't say so.

But under 392, this judicial proceeding that we have under the Family Court Act, the child is there, and it's presumed that he will be because there's a statutory section in that, 392(6), which says that the court may dispense with the presence of the child.
So it obviously is contemplated that the child will be there and will be heard unless the court feels that it's not necessary.

turn.text: Your time has expired, Ms. Marcus.
Thank you ladies.
The case is submitted.
